Author: mparris
Content:
I agree that docker will become the defacto way to deploy software. It removes so many variables between the desk of the developer and the deployment. Changing versions of software is rediculously easy, so rolling back after an upgrade doesn't go well is always option. The configuration-as-code with immutable containers makes deployment very repeatable, which, again, removes variables and simplifies the process.

We use docker and Portainer to orchestrate our custom applications, which then orchestrate some production systems. We view Portainer as a management of infrastructure. 

Lately, I've been diving deeper into Cybersecurity... looking to use docker to deploy asset inventory software as well as secure remote access software deeper into the OT space.

The biggest needs are to streamline bringing up bare metal into the ecosystem, then streamlining deployment of an application or stack of applications onto that bare metal, then being able to monitor all their health at scale

Author: .killnine
Content:
What do you mean 'container management system'? You mean an orchestrator like k8s or actual container runtimes like Docker and Podman?

Docker's [guidance](https://docs.docker.com/engine/security/rootless/) includes running as rootless if your environment's containers can get away it. But it's also essential that whatever system is actuall executing the Docker daemon is fairly hardened as well.

Lots of container images that I run of popular software (ex: SQL Server) have made strides in not running as root, and running on thin base images really reduces the attack surface of them as well.

While it wouldn't be my first 'value add' for containerized environments, I do think the net-net of containerization is improved security attack surfaces.

I'd say generally it's discouraged from ever running as root and I don't think orchestrators or runtimes are kicking the can on security. It's just very complicated to make a one-size-fits-all solution and you need knowledgable people in the organization to correctly configure the environment per the needs of the business

Content:
I have plenty of kubernetes experience, and a little with highbyte.
There are several ways to configure kubernetes depending on what the application you are hosting supports. For non-clustered applications it we be automatically spinning up a new instance in a similar way to docker restart-always.
For clustered applications you can get more sophisticated with rolling updates.

Author: slamber12
Content: Thanks! I‚Äôm not sure of the terminology this part is all foreign to me but I‚Äôm told Kubernetes may automatically restart a pod if it sees an issue with performance? If there is data in a pipeline queue (pipeline is slower than incoming data - back pressure issue) when this happens, I am told this queue is totally lost, poof. This is really bad in a GXP world so I‚Äôm just trying to understand if we‚Äôre doing something wrong or if we should take a different approach

Author: slamber12
Content: And to be fair I don‚Äôt expect our production data to actually exceed the pipeline but we‚Äôre testing performance limits and it‚Äôs possible some data producer could have an error and create this problem

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Kubernetes will try to restart a pod if it becomes unhealthy. If the application you are running does not persist it's data to a shared volume in a durable way, the data would indeed be lost. Think a pod like a virtual server. When kubernetes restarts a pod, it throws the server in the bin and makes a completely new one.
Data that needs to be persisted across server restarts must be stored in volumes that are outside the pod, just like network attached storage for servers.

Author: aronsemle
Content: Gotcha, yeah what you probably want to do is configure a pipeline that reads the MQTT topic(s) and writes them to disk (aka the volume) and then another pipeline that reads these in chunks from the volume and processes them. Once it's done it clears the messages it processed from the storage. This way you on a reboot you won't lose anything. It will create delays because of the I/O but you should be able to tune the reads to process N events at a time to make it more efficient I'm guessing
